subject: Add Erase verifyGeometry
commitMessage:
Add Erase verifyGeometry

This confirms specified amount of the drive is accessible. The min and
max expected drive size are set as a build configuration, and compared
against the drive size (found by using the linux ioctl). Also adds
testing build files, testing options, and verifyGeometry test.

Tested: Ran eStoraged on a machine with an eMMC, using the following
$ ./eStoraged -b /dev/mmcblk0 &
$ busctl call  xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.mmcblk0 \
 /xyz/openbmc_project/storage/mmcblk0 \
 xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged Erase ays 1 1 \
 xyz.openbmc_project.eStoraged.EraseMethod.VerifyGeometry

Signed-off-by: John Edward Broadbent <jebr@google.com>
Change-Id: Ie47f8666996a6085a115d1b86f2643bc278638c5

typo
Done
fix
Done
Class names should be upper camelcase https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#naming-conventions
fixed in patchset 21

What if there are multiple storage devices of different sizes?

The minimum geometry could maybe be in the form of a percentage, if we want that to be a build option applicable to all the devices. But maybe the device size could be an argument to eStoraged?

> What if there are multiple storage devices of different sizes?
Recipes can override build options. Currently the plan is to have multiple instances of estoraged for the mutli eMMC case. So this is could be dealt with in the recipe.

> The minimum geometry could maybe be in the form of a percentage, if we want that to be a build option applicable to all the devices. 

I suppose I would have to have expected size, percent above, percent below. 
With out the expected size I would be unable to detrimen if the current size is in range.

> But maybe the device size could be an argument to eStoraged?
Maybe, we could also provide it in configuration files (set up by the recipe) that estoraged reads in this step. There are several fine approaches. 

My understanding is the size of the drives can not be shared in this publicly.

Something like a config file would give us the flexibility to specify different sizes for different devices. But since we don't have any immediate plans to use this with multiple storage devices, maybe we can set that up later, if and when it's needed.

I agree. 
I will add a note of our intention to add a config file if the number of storage devices increases
is verify geometry only used during erase?
Class names should be UpperCamelCase.

I had a to change it to VerifyDriveGeometry to avoid a name collision with the interface VerfyGeometry. 
Done
yes (right now). It is part the erase process
This description doesn't match the option. Same is true with the other option, as well.
done
Is there a reason for not making this function a member of the VerifyGeometry class?

- It use is not limited to VerifyGeomenty. (Other methods also need to know the size of the device.)
- It does not need any of the verifyGeometry state to find the size
- I pass this in as an std::fuction, which can be done for a member function, but that can be unclear. (minor)
Does this function only get used in the context of erasing? Could it be part of the erase class?

> Does this function only get used in the context of erasing? 
Currently it's only use is in erasing. However, there are sections of the code not yet implemented 
 
> Could it be part of the erase class?
It could be part of the erase class. Should it be part of the erase class? I assume that other parts of the estoraged will need this function, or we will save the size of drive in so we don't have to check multiple times. Eventually it will be moved to the src in it's own hpp and cpp, and it will populate a value in the estoraged class. But I can't tell the future (I am barely tell the present;)

I feel uneasy about this being just an extern function with declaration in `include/verifyGeometry.hpp` for some reason (I guess I just don't see this much?)

I would also find a home for this in a class personally - makes it easier for mocking and testing later. I'd also be curious on how these classes will be tested if defined this way.

Sounds good.
This function is passed into member function GeometryOkay(std::function, unint_t64)

For me to pass a member fucntion into another member function will require the use of either std::bind or a lambda, do you have a preference?
I made it a member function of erase.
Can you add unit tests for verifyGeometry?

There is a separate change here:
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/48608/3

It is the first unit test of the project, so it has more changes then normal changes.
Prefer to squash the 2 commits if possible so that we have a change and the accommodating unit test (so that presubmit will show us that the changes are well tested).

squashed: https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/48608/3 into this commit in patch set 20. 
see https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/48607/19..20 for the diff.
Is this necessary? I thought the purpose of verifyGeometry was simply to check that the logical size is at least a certain percentage of the physical size.
Other implementations do this check. It does not require us to, but it does make sense to me.

If this is still an issue feel free to reopen

Thanks.
There should be a build file in the erase directory.
done?
You should set up a static_library in the new build file under erase/.

Can you help me understand why we want a static library for the erase section. 
Is there another application that is going to link against erase?
Or do we want the binaries to match the subdirectors?

Or maybe there are advantages of static_library, that I am not aware of. 
Thank you.
It's convention for the build structure to follow the directory structure. So, you would have a library and declare_dependency in the build file under erase/
done, thanks for your help.
This function doesn't return bool.
In the future version it throws an dbus defined error
nit: Add instead of adds, as explained in the previous commit as per https://chris.beams.io/posts/git-commit/#imperative

lower camelcase for variables https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#naming-conventions
We should use std::string_view instead.

We wont be able to use the initialization list if I use a string view here.
We will have to deep copy it, right? That feel slower.

I can use move to force the the fastest initialization.
Ack
Here too https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#naming-conventions

really really minor nit: if we want to capitalize, we should capitalize the first line "If" and small case "In" on the second line

Thanks for catching this. I am glad you have such a great eye for detail.

I agree, the capitalization should be consistent.

Done

Just noticed, should these be const & for all the vectors here?
Make sense, but these are generated from sdbusplus. I took a very quick look and did not a sdbusplus parameter type that would let us send const bytes.

I have not found a way to change how sdbusplus is generating this interface.
Feel free to reopen if this is still an issue.
nit: I wonder if we should name this libeToragedErase_dep since this seems to be dependencies

That would be more consistent
I will also move it the src/erase/meson.build if that is okay

Done
Just have it take the size instead of having it execute a function just to use the return value.
That is a much better idea
Just include the linux uapi header?
Done
Prefer returning the value and throwing exceptions otherwise.
sounds good, returning value, and throwing generated exceptions
Missing close later, personally I would use https://github.com/openbmc/stdplus/blob/master/src/stdplus/fd/managed.hpp

done, 
I am am not very familiar with it, but it looks to match my use case well
You should have an error class defined in the dbus interface and throw it here. Also no cout.

you are right.
Done
nit: trailing slash

done
(I changed it everywhere)
Needs to start with upper-case, I think

I was under the impression that function (including member fuctions) should start with lower case.
See:
https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#functions
and
https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/estoraged/+/48607/12/include/verifyGeometry.hpp#17
Yup, class is UpperCamelCase, function/members are lowerCamelCase
It seems like this should be a void function, since we use exceptions to indicate an error. Returning 0 in the success case seems redundant.

Sounds good.

These test names could be more descriptive, e.g. TooBigFail, TooSmallFail, etc.
Done
Interesting, I guess I've never seen this done like this

I took it from bmcweb 
https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/blob/master/bmcweb.socket.in#L5

Do we *need* to declare this a separate string to pass to lg2::error? or could we just have it as part of lg2::error similar to the other strings?

Same with below

I've been fighting with lg2 recently, as well. You can't seem to simply pass in the literal string in quotes. But you can explicitly call the string constructor when you pass the string as a function parameter, e.g. std::string("asdf")
Yeah, it's really goofy design (one of the things I had an issue with during design review). I was looking into fixing this upstream but haven't spent much time on it.

I change all the usages to be the way Wedig recommends it.
Create the string in the function parameter list.
It is an odd design to me
Ack

extra spaces

Has this been tested on a machine? If so, it would be a good idea to add a "Tested:" section to the commit message.
added a testing section after I preformed the test
Is this being used?

I needed for for the open flag iirc.
It is not needed anymore.
This shouldn't be needed.
Done
Shouldn't all of these comments be located just above their respective functions?
Done
nit: this seems wrong?

yeah, it looks goofy. Putting it on one line.

the "<" is used by doxygen to denote order: see doxygen.nl/manual/docblocks.html 
(I can get rid of it if you want)
Oh, sorry just saw this. Technically we need to get rid of < now since we're not using the member dockblock inline.
Done
nit: size_t instead?

Maybe, size_t is 32 or 64 depending on the architecture. 32 bits will only represent 4.2 GB, 
our chips uses a arm cortext A9 which is 32 bits for size_t. So switching to size_t will causes unexpected failures (not in x86 docker, where size_t is 64 bits)

I could change the ioctl to be the older version of get size in blocks, the get block size. Or I could convert size in bytes to size in KB. Using a 64bit int might be the cleanest, let me know what you think.

Ah yeah, sounds like we have a good rationale for using uint64_t - just wanted to point out https://github.com/openbmc/docs/blob/master/cpp-style-and-conventions.md#misc-guidelines where size_t should be used on size, positions, counts, etc. as much as possible.
nit: prefer separate line comment rather than inline. Let's put this above the declaration
sounds good
We generally prefer to pass string_views if we are going to store in a string anyway. It would reduce all but the final needed copy.

I used to need a c_string to open a file, that is typically done by creating a  std::string from a string_view then use the real string to create the c_string. It felt strange passing a string_view only to immediately create a new std::string.
 
I don't know if the std++ will let me open a file with only a std::string
I thought William intended for your class member devPath to still be a string. My understanding was that only the constructor parameter inDevPath needs to be a string_view, but I'll let him clarify.
Yeah, ultimately the class should store an std::string since it needs to outlive the input parameters potentially. I was just saying the input arguments should be string_views.
Done
You don't need to provide an input file if you are just doing trivial value setting.

The goals is too allow Expected size for the eMMC can be set in the recipe, so they are not public, and easily changed . Wedig and I also discussed reading this information from a config file, or having it passed in as arguments at start. What are your thoughts?
 
I could verifyDriveGeometry.cpp and verifyGeometry_test.cpp as a meson config files, letting me use @ERASE_*_GEOMETRY@ in it, and making this file unnecessary?

My suggestion wasn't against using compile time params, just that you don't need to explicitly define a header file to have contents filled in. You can take advantage of meson doing this for you.

https://mesonbuild.com/Configuration.html#configuring-without-an-input-file

"I didn't realize that was an option"
That is neat, done
Yeah, my first comment wasn't really clear about keeping the config file but having it be autogenerated.
Don't include things in the header that aren't used here. Prefer to add them to the CPP file.

good call, I forgot to remove them
done
Pass a string_view
Done
nit: No need for a temporary string representation.
done
Prefer `stdplus::fd::open` as it checks the error status from fd. I know I didn't add O_NDELAY, but it shouldn't do anything since you don't read / write?
Done
No need to check RC, fd.ioctl internally throws an exception if it is negative so this is a noop.
neat, done
Ack
You might consider dropping the default so that you get a compilation error if new enum definitions are added.
makes sense

I would copy this iteration of the gtest stuff as it fixes warnings and missing thread dependency.

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-networkd/blob/master/test/meson.build#L1
I guess you will want to consolidate this with the other test change that Wedig committed.

I moved my testing stuff into what John Wedig meson
Thanks for looking at it
Same here, stdplus::fd::open throws and exception automatically. You might want to try { } catch if you need specific errors to be propagated upstack and have log output printed.
sounds good, I added try and catch, and would like to propagate errors up to the dbus interface error.
nit: You can drop .c_str for this call. There is an std::string parameterized version.

cool, it works.
I did not see it the fd/create.cpp?
 
https://github.com/openbmc/stdplus/blob/fd0f551cbdd26229dcdcfde2d6195bdf9f258197/src/stdplus/fd/create.cpp#L12
It's in the header
The case here is different from below?
no. I will combine them
These messages are the same, collapse the calls into a single try / catch. The error output from the exception could explain the failure anyway to give unique information.
sounds good, I will collapse it.
#pragma once
